knowledge_graph.title: Kefir
knowledge_graph.description: Kefir is a fermented milk drink similar to a thin yogurt or ayran that is made from kefir grains, a specific type of mesophilic symbiotic culture. It is prepared by inoculating the milk of cows, goats, or sheep with kefir grains.

immersive_products.title: Cultures for Health Water Kefir Grains
Cultures For Health Kefir Starter Culture

related_questions.question: What does drinking kefir do for you?
related_questions.snippet: Kefir is a fermented drink made with milk or water and kefir grains. Its consistency and flavor are similar to yogurt drinks, but kefir has more probiotics and good bacteria. Several studies show that drinking kefir can help improve your digestive and bone health and maintain your blood sugar levels.
related_questions.title: What Are Kefir and Its Health Benefits? - WebMD

related_questions.question: Is it safe to drink kefir everyday?
related_questions.snippet: Kefir is most often used by adults in doses of 400-500 mL by mouth daily for up to 4 weeks. Lower doses of 100-180 mL daily have been used for up to 12 weeks. Speak with a healthcare provider to find out what dose might be best for a specific condition.
related_questions.title: KEFIR - Uses, Side Effects, and More - WebMD

related_questions.question: Is kefir better for you than yogurt?
related_questions.snippet: The biggest nutritional difference between the two is that kefir contains more probiotics than yogurt. While yogurt also contains some probiotics, kefir is more potent. If you are looking to improve digestion or gut health, kefir is the better choice.
related_questions.title: Kefir vs. Yogurt: Nutrition, Uses, Where to Buy, and More - Healthline

related_questions.question: What does kefir taste like?
related_questions.snippet: How should it taste? The kefir should taste yogurty and tangy, but it usually lacks the slightly sweet aftertaste of yogurt. If you've tasted shop bought kefir, you might be in for a bit of a surprise at first, but you really can learn to love the homemade variety.
related_questions.title: How to make kefir - BBC Good Food

answer_box.title: Kefir: What is it, health benefits, dangers, and how to make it

hover_info.info: Fermented milk products or fermented dairy products, also known as cultured dairy foods, cultured dairy products, or cultured milk products, are dairy foods that have been made by fermenting milk with lactic acid bacteria such as Lactobacillus, Lactococcus, and Leuconostoc.
hover_info.title: List of fermented milk products - Wikipedia

answer_box.snippet: Kefir is a type of fermented milk that may help manage blood sugar, lower cholesterol, and boost digestive health, among other benefits. However, more evidence is needed to back some of these claims. The name kefir comes from the Turkish word “keyif,” which refers to the “good feeling” a person gets after drinking it.
snippet_highlighted_words: a type of fermented milk that may help manage blood sugar, lower cholesterol, and boost digestive health

organic_results.title: KEFIR - Uses, Side Effects, and More
organic_results.snippet: Kefir is a creamy and tart probiotic drink that's made by adding kefir grains to milk and allowing it to ferment. The grains contain bacteria and yeast.

buttons.subtitle: What Does Kefir Do To Your Stomach
buttons.title: What Are Kefir and Its Health Benefits? - WebMD
buttons.snippet: Kefir can have as many as 61 strains of bacteria. Studies show these powerful microorganisms may help treat and prevent gastrointestinal diseases like irritable bowel syndrome, some kinds of diarrhea, and ulcers caused by the infection H. pylori.
snippet_highlighted_words: help treat and prevent gastrointestinal diseases like irritable bowel syndrome, some kinds of diarrhea, and ulcers caused by the infection H.

buttons.subtitle: What Does Kefir Taste Like?
buttons.title: How to make kefir - BBC Good Food
buttons.snippet: How should it taste? The kefir should taste yogurty and tangy, but it usually lacks the slightly sweet aftertaste of yogurt. If you've tasted shop bought kefir, you might be in for a bit of a surprise at first, but you really can learn to love the homemade variety.

buttons.subtitle: What Is Kefir Used For
buttons.title: 9 Evidence-Based Health Benefits of Kefir - Healthline
buttons.snippet: Kefir is a healthy fermented food with a consistency comparable to drinkable yogurt. This product is traditionally made from dairy milk, but plenty of nondairy options are available. Studies suggest that it boosts your immune system, aids in digestive problems, improves bone health, and may even combat cancer.
snippet_highlighted_words: boosts your immune system, aids in digestive problems, improves bone health, and may even combat cancer

buttons.subtitle: What Are The Side Effects Of Raw Kefir
buttons.title: KEFIR: Overview, Uses, Side Effects, Precautions, Interactions ... - WebMD
buttons.snippet: Side effects might include bloating, nausea, stomach cramps, diarrhea, and constipation. These symptoms usually go away after continued use. Pregnancy and breast-feeding: There isn't enough reliable information to know if kefir is safe to use when pregnant or breast-feeding. Stay on the safe side and avoid use.
snippet_highlighted_words: bloating, nausea, stomach cramps, diarrhea, and constipation

buttons.subtitle: Is Kefir A Probiotic Or Prebiotic
buttons.title: Kefir: What It Is, Benefits, and Risks - ZOE
buttons.snippet: Kefir contains millions of probiotics, which are bacteria with potential health benefits. It's also low in lactose and packed with vitamins and minerals that are good for your body. Scientists have found a range of possible health benefits of kefir, including improved cholesterol, blood sugar control, and gut health.

buttons.subtitle: What Can You Use Kefir For
buttons.title: 8 Ways to Eat Kefir - Kalona SuperNatural
list: Drink it! This is probably the most common and simple way to eat kefir. ...
Pour it over your cereal just like you would milk. Kefir makes a great tangy and tart base for your breakfast!

buttons.subtitle: How Much Kefir Should I Drink A Day?
buttons.title: Can You Drink Too Much Kefir? - Healthline
buttons.snippet: How much should you drink? Kefir can be a healthy and delicious addition to a well-rounded diet. For best results, stick to around 1–3 cups (237–710 mL) per day and pair it with a variety of other fermented foods and beverages to increase your intake of probiotics.

buttons.subtitle: How To Make Kefir
buttons.title: Homemade kefir recipe - BBC Good Food
buttons.snippet: Put ½ tsp kefir grains in the jar. Add the milk, leaving about 2cm head room if using a clip top jar, or at least 5cm for a cloth-covered jar. Set aside at room temperature for 18-24 hrs to ferment. It's turned to kefir when the milk has thickened.
snippet_highlighted_words: Put ½ tsp kefir grains in the jar.
Add the milk, leaving about 2cm head room if using a clip top jar, or at least 5cm for a cloth-covered jar.
Set aside at room temperature for 18-24 hrs to ferment

buttons.subtitle: What Kind Of Milk Is Kefir?
buttons.title: What Kind of Milk Do I Use To Make Kefir? - Cultured Food Life
buttons.snippet: Pasteurized and homogenized is the most common type of milk that is used to make kefir. It's the one I use most often, although I love raw milk kefir and goat kefir too. Regular pasteurized milk HTST (high-temperature short time) makes great kefir and is affordable.
